title: Is this the Civil Demand Letter? Came directly from Nordstrom?
question: I was caught shoplifting at Nordstrom about a couple weeks ago. Items totaled to be roughly $85, but no police were contacted. I gave my info (DL, SSN, address, photo) to Nordstrom, and they said they would keep it with the store only.
answers:
They can but I have yet to see either a store or law firm follow through with the threat to file a civil lawsuit, probably because the filing fee would be close to, or more than the demand itself. Seems like an overwhelming consensus amongst the attorneys on Avvo agree that no response is probably the best way to approach this situation. Good luck.
PLEASE NOTE THAT THE FOREGOING IS OPINION ONLY AND NOT LEGAL ADVICE NOR DOES IT CREATE AN ATTORNEY-CLIENT RELATIONSHIP.

There's nothing that prevents a store from cutting out the middle man.

The law firms that send out civil demand letters work on commission, taking a percentage of what they take. Since they're just paper-pushers who don't really so anything that requires an attorney, the merchant has apparently decided to cut them out of the action.

Bottom line: ignore them. The letter sounds like it's full of the same "weasel words" a law firm would include. For instance, they say they "may commence civil legal action" instead of coming out and saying "pay up or we'll sue." That's because it's a violation of Federal debt collection laws to threaten to sue if they don't really intend to follow through.
